questions.text: Which of the following lipid storage disorder presents with Cherry Red Spot in Macula? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tay Sach's disease

 

Tay Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder that characteristically presents with a cherry-red spot in the macula. This appearance is due to the accumulation of gangliosides in the retinal ganglion cells, causing the macula to appear pale and contrasting with the normal red color of the fovea, creating the cherry-red spot appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gaucher's disease: While it may cause pseudo cherry-red spot and not a true cherry-red spot in ophthalmology.

 

Option C. Krabbe's disease: This is a leukodystrophy that primarily affects the nervous system but does not typically cause a cherry-red spot in the macula.

 

Option D. Fabry's disease: While this condition can affect the eyes, it typically causes corneal verticillata (corneal whorls) rather than a cherry-red spot in the macula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cherry-red spot in the macula is a characteristic finding in several lipid storage disorders, with Tay Sachs disease being the most notable.

 

The mnemonic "BeE STING" can be helpful in remembering causes of cherry-red spot: Berlin's Edema, Sclerosis, Tay-Sachs, Ischemia (CRAO), Niemann-Pick, and GM1 Gangliosidosis.

questions.text: Identify this laparoscopic image? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genital tuberculosis

 

The laparoscopic image shows two key diagnostic features of genital tuberculosis:

 

  1. "Kissing fallopian tube sign" - where the fallopian tubes are stuck together posteriorly
  2. Presence of caseous (whitish) nodules These findings are pathognomonic for genital tuberculosis on laparoscopy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Tubal endometriosis: In tubal endometriosis, the tubes are typically adherent to the posterior surface of the uterus, and reddish-blackish or whitish lesions are seen over the tube. This pattern is not seen in the image.

 

Option C. Hydrosalpinx: While hydrosalpinx can occur in genital tuberculosis, it has a different appearance with dilated fallopian tubes. The image does not show dilated tubes.

 

Option D. Chocolate cyst: This is an endometriotic ovarian cyst containing dark brown material. In the image, the ovaries are not visible as they are likely behind the uterus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The "kissing fallopian tube sign" along with caseous nodules on laparoscopy is diagnostic of genital tuberculosis.
  • Fallopian tubes are the most common organs affected in genital TB

questions.text: Following sign is seen in (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

 

Explanation: 


The image shows the Holman-Miller sign (or antral sign), which is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). This sign is characterized by:

 

  • Forward bowing/anterior displacement of the posterior wall of maxillary sinus
  • Occurs due to tumor extension from sphenopalatine foramen into pterygopalatine fossa
  • The tumor exerts pressure from behind, pushing the posterior maxillary wall forward
  • This finding is visible on CT scan and is a key diagnostic feature of JNA

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

  • Shows Trotter's triad (palatal palsy, ipsilateral neuralgia, conductive hearing loss)
  • No characteristic anterior bowing of posterior maxillary wall
  • Most commonly arises from fossa of Rosenmuller

 

Option C. Tear drop sign

 

  • Also called hanging drop sign
  • Seen in orbital floor fractures (blow-out fractures)
  • Not related to maxillary wall displacement

 

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis

 

  • Shows strawberry-like lesions in nasal cavity
  • Presents with epistaxis
  • No characteristic changes in maxillary sinus wall

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

choices.text: Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Isthmus because of narrowest area
Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Ampulla because of narrowest area

questions.text: The most common site of tubal ligation and the reason for ligation at this site is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isthmus because of narrowest area

 

The most common site for tubal ligation is the isthmus of the fallopian tube. The isthmus is the narrowest portion of the tube, which makes it an ideal site for ligation. One key reason for selecting this site is that it preserves the broader segments of the tube, such as the ampulla, which are essential if recanalization (reversal of the ligation) is needed later. By ligating the narrowest part, the wider and more functionally significant areas remain intact, facilitating easier and more successful surgical reanastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: This is incorrect because the reason for ligating at the isthmus is primarily its narrowness, not muscle structure.

 

Option C. Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: The ampulla is not the preferred site for ligation because it is wider and more functionally significant. Ligation here would complicate future recanalization procedures.

 

Option D. Ampulla because of narrowest area: This is incorrect because the ampulla is not the narrowest part of the fallopian tube; the isthmus is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus is the most common site for tubal ligation due to its narrowness, which preserves the broader, more functional parts of the tube, making recanalization easier if needed in the future.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following aortic arches causes the defect shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 6th left

 

The image depicts a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

 

Normally, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. However, in cases of PDA, the ductus arteriosus fails to close, leading to abnormal blood flow between the two major arteries.

 

Presentation - Hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

 

Treatment options for PDA include medication, minimally invasive catheter-based procedures, and surgical closure. Medications like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be given to encourage closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

The aortic arch arteries, also referred to as the branchial or pharyngeal arch arteries, are a series of six paired arterial structures that arise from the aortic sac during embryonic development. They play a crucial role in the formation of the major arteries of the head, neck, and thorax. Abnormal development or persistence of these arteries can lead to a range of congenital anomalies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 4th left and Option B. 4th right: These arches are primarily involved in forming parts of the aorta and its major branches, not directly related to the defect depicted in the image.

 

Option D. 6th right: While the right 6th arch also contributes to the development of the pulmonary artery system, its defects are usually not associated with PDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here's a list of defects related to the aortic arch arteries:

 

  1. Double Aortic Arch: This involves the persistence of both the right and left fourth aortic arches. It can form a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus, which can cause respiratory and feeding difficulties.
  2. Right Aortic Arch: This results from the regression of the left fourth aortic arch. Depending on the persistence of the ductus arteriosus, different types can form, some of which can lead to a vascular ring.
  3. Interrupted Aortic Arch: Here, there's a complete loss of continuity between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta. It's often associated with other congenital heart defects.
  4. Persistent Truncus Arteriosus: This is a failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta, leading to a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart supplying both systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations.
  5. Coarctation of the Aorta: It's a narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the site of the ductus arteriosus. It can lead to high blood pressure in the upper body and arms and lower blood pressure in the lower body and legs.
  6. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes, but in this condition, it remains open, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery.
  7. Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery: This is a variant in the branching pattern where the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch and can course posterior to the esophagus.
  8. Cervical Aortic Arch: Here, the aortic arch is positioned higher than normal in the neck. It is usually of no clinical significance but can be identified radiologically.
  9. Aortopulmonary Septal Defects: These defects involve abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  10. Vascular Rings: These are congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches that encircle and compress the trachea and esophagus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for successive recurrent pregnancy losses. On ultrasound, a Mullerian anomaly is suspected. What is the BEST way to confirm this? (NEET PF 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy:

 

  • Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy is considered the best invasive method to confirm the diagnosis of Mullerian anomalies. This approach allows direct visualization of both the internal and external contours of the uterus.
  • During the procedure, hysteroscopy can evaluate the endometrial cavity, while laparoscopy can assess the external uterine surface and other pelvic structures.
  • This combination not only confirms the diagnosis but also allows for simultaneous corrective surgery, if necessary (e.g., resecting a uterine septum).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a useful imaging technique for evaluating the shape and patency of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. However, it may not provide detailed information about the external contour of the uterus or distinguish between certain types of Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: While laparoscopy alone can provide information about the external structure of the uterus and other pelvic organs, it does not allow for direct visualization of the endometrial cavity. Combining it with hysteroscopy gives a more comprehensive assessment.

 

Option D. Transvaginal sonography: Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect many uterine anomalies. However, it may not be as definitive as hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, especially for complex anomalies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The best way to confirm a suspected Mullerian anomaly is through hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, which allows for a comprehensive assessment and potential simultaneous treatment.

 

Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A partogram of a woman in labor is shown below. Oxytocin infusion has been administered. Mark the best management for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

The above partogram suggests that the woman has cephalopelvic disproportion, for which the management would be to perform an emergency caesarean section.

 

According to the above given partogram, findings are

 

  • Cervix is fully dilated
  • Moulding is 2+ = Sutures are overlapped but reducible
  • Station is 3+
  • Oxytocin infusion administered.
  • Uterine contractions - Adequate.
  • Amniotic fluid - M = Meconium-stained fluid
  • Fetal heart rate – Deceleration = Baby is in distress
  • Descent: Head is 3/5th palpable; this means that an instrument cannot be applied. For either forceps of vacuum to be applied, the head should not be palpable per abdomen.

 

In case of fetal distress, the management is an emergency cesarean section, not instrumental delivery or elective cesarean section.

 

Cephalopelvic disproportion means there is a disproportion in the fetal head and pelvis. It could be due to a Contracted pelvis or large baby (Macrosomia)

 

Degrees of Disproportion

 

  1. Severe degree contracted pelvis: Obstetric conjugate < 7.5 cm
  2. Moderate degree: Obstetric conjugate between 7.5 to 9.5 cm
  3. Borderline pelvis: Obstetric conjugate measures between 9.5 to 10 cm

 

Obstructed labor is one where despite good uterine contractions, the progressive descent of the presenting part is arrested due to mechanical obstruction. Cephalopelvic disproportion and contracted pelvis are the common causes.

 

A cesarean section at term is should be done in these cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Forceps-assisted delivery: Not suitable because the head is still palpable per abdomen and forceps cannot be applied.

 

Option B. Vacuum-assisted delivery: Not appropriate due to the same reason as above; the head is still palpable per abdomen.

 

Option C. Oxytocin infusion: Oxytocin infusion is already being administered, and increasing or continuing it won't resolve the issue of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of cephalopelvic disproportion and fetal distress, as indicated by a partogram, the management should be an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: Outbreak of diarrhea. Rice water stool in nature. Pathogen exhibited darting motility. What is the organism? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vibrio cholerae

 

Characteristic features of Vibrio cholera:

 

  • Rice water stool: This is a characteristic symptom of cholera, which is caused by Vibrio cholerae. The stool looks similar to the water left after washing rice, which is a key indicator of this infection.
  • Darting motility: Vibrio cholerae exhibits a unique form of motility known as darting motility. This type of movement resembles a shooting star, which is rapid and straight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Salmonella typhi: This bacterium causes typhoid fever, not characterized by rice water stools or darting motility.

 

Option C. E. coli: While certain strains of E. coli can cause diarrhea, they do not produce rice water stools nor do they exhibit darting motility. Their motility is usually peritrichous flagella-based.

 

Option D. Shigella dysentriae: This pathogen causes dysentery, characterized by bloody diarrhea, not rice water stools. It also does not exhibit darting motility; its movement is typically more sluggish.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of motility:

questions.text: A patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide, having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Feeding jejunostomy

 

  • Since the patient is in complete dysphagia, a feeding jejunostomy is the next best step.

 

CAUSTIC INJURY

 

Most common in children or people with psychiatric illness

 

Alkali poison – liquefactive necrosis

 

Management – Emergency → stabilise the patient

 

  • Endoscopy to assess the injury
  • No perforation – conservative management + feeding by NG feed / NJ feed / gastrostomy or jejunostomy
  • Serial endoscopic assessment – usually after 3-6 months → elective reconstruction → esophagectomy + conduit (gastric / colonic)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophago-jejunostomy : Esophago-jejunostomy is avoided in acute setting.

 

Option B. Stent placement: Esophageal stenting may not be useful if injury extends to stomach.

 

Option D. Gastrojejunostomy: Procedures on stomach are avoided until extent of injury is assessed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with complete dysphagia following the ingestion of a strong alkali like sodium hydroxide, the best immediate management step is the insertion of a feeding jejunostomy to provide nutritional support while assessing and stabilizing the patient.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient comes with hoarseness of voice and difficulty swallowing. The patient was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma and surgical management was done. The post-operative image of the patient is given below. Which of the following surgery was done on this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total laryngectomy

 

The given clinical scene and image shows a post-op tracheal stump created for breathing in patients of total laryngectomy for laryngeal carcinoma.

 

In total laryngectomy, the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more rings of trachea, are removed. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration.

 

Complications after total laryngectomy:

 

  • Permanent tracheostomy: upper end of trachea is directly sutured to skin for the patient to breathe.
  • Speech difficulties: To help patient speak after removal of larynx, there are various techniques.

 

1. Oesophageal speech:  patient is taught to swallow air and release which vibrates pharyngo-oesophageal segment and produces a very low sound.

 

2. Tracheo-oesophageal speech: most effective, artificial prostheses like Blom-singer valve / Provox / Groningen are inserted.

 

3. Electrolarynx: electrical device held on the skin of the neck vibrates and produce voice.

 

  • Loss of smell and decreased taste sensation
  • Swallowing difficulty

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial laryngectomy: Is performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening.

 

Option B. Percutaneous tracheostomy: Is a minimally invasive surgical procedure done in ICU patients to create an opening in the trachea for breathing support. The image below shows the procedure of percutaneous tracheostomy.

 

 

Option C. Standard tracheostomy: Involves creating a larger incision in the neck to access the trachea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total laryngectomy is a radical yet life-saving procedure for patients with extensive laryngeal cancer, resulting in significant anatomical and functional changes.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of rivaroxaban is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xa inhibitor

 

Rivaroxaban is an oral anticoagulant that works by inhibiting Factor Xa, a crucial enzyme in the blood coagulation cascade. The name "rivaroxaban" itself hints at its mechanism of action, where "Xa" refers to Factor Xa, and "ban" suggests inhibition. By inhibiting Factor Xa, rivaroxaban prevents the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin, thus reducing the formation of fibrin clots. This inhibition is crucial in preventing and treating conditions such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), and reducing the risk of stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation.

 

Other Xa blocker drugs: Apixaban, Edoxaban, Betrixaban

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IIa inhibitor: IIa refers to thrombin (Factor IIa), and while inhibiting thrombin is another anticoagulation strategy, rivaroxaban does not act on Factor IIa. Instead, drugs like dabigatran work as direct thrombin inhibitors.

 

Option C. Vitamin K antagonist: This refers to a different class of anticoagulants, such as warfarin, which inhibit the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors. Rivaroxaban does not affect vitamin K or its associated pathways.

 

Option D. Antithrombin activation: Antithrombin activation is the mechanism of action for drugs like heparin. Rivaroxaban does not work by activating antithrombin but rather by directly inhibiting Factor Xa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rivaroxaban is a direct, reversible inhibitor of Factor Xa, a key enzyme in the blood coagulation process, and is used as an anticoagulant.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student with a 2-month history of palpitations, sweating, and restlessness. He also complains of a sweaty palm. His appearance is as shown in the picture. What is the next step in evaluation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ultrasensitive thyrotropin

 

The patient's symptoms and the clinical image strongly suggest Graves' Orbitopathy (also known as Graves' Ophthalmopathy), characterized by proptosis, eyelid edema, and eye congestion. The most common cause of both unilateral and bilateral exophthalmos is Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism.

 

The next step in evaluating a patient suspected of having hyperthyroidism is to perform a thyroid function test (TFT), with the most important initial test being the measurement of Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH). The ultrasensitive thyrotropin test, which measures TSH levels, is crucial because it helps in determining the presence of hyperthyroidism.

 

In Graves' disease, TSH levels are typically very low or undetectable, while free T4 and Total T3 levels are elevated (primary hyperthyroidism).

 

IOC – MRI of the orbit

 

TOC – mild – moderate disease – conservative management

 

Mod.-severe disease – first line TOC – CS (Dexamethasone); Teprotumumab (IGF1 receptor inhibitor Mab)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thyroid receptor antibody: This test is specific for confirming Graves' disease, but it is not the first step. It is used after initial thyroid function tests suggest hyperthyroidism to confirm the diagnosis. The antibodies known as TRAb (TSH receptor antibody/ Thyroid receptor Ab).

 

2 forms of TRAb – TSI (Thyroid Stimulating Immunoglobulin) and

                -  TBII (Thyroid binding Inhibitory Immunoglobulin)

 

Option B. Radioactive Iodine Uptake: This test helps to differentiate between various causes of hyperthyroidism, such as Graves' disease and toxic multinodular goiter. It is not the first step but follows initial thyroid function tests if hyperthyroidism is confirmed.

 

Option D. Anti thyroid peroxidase antibody: This antibody is not specific for Graves' disease. It is more commonly associated with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and other autoimmune thyroid disorders, making it less relevant for initial evaluation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first and most crucial test in the evaluation of suspected hyperthyroidism, such as in a case suggestive of Graves' disease, is the measurement of ultrasensitive thyrotropin (TSH) levels.

 

Confirmatory Diagnosis – by TRAbs (Thyroid receptor antibodies)

questions.text: Laryngismus stridulus is caused by deficiency of:  (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a characteristic feature of severe rickets, which is caused by vitamin D deficiency. In severe cases of rickets, profound vitamin D deficiency leads to significant hypocalcemia. This low calcium level can cause muscle spasms, including spasm of the larynx, resulting in laryngismus stridulus. The condition is characterized by sudden, brief episodes of stridor (high-pitched breathing sound) due to laryngeal spasm.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Incorrect. While vitamin A deficiency can cause various health issues, including night blindness and increased susceptibility to infections, it is not associated with laryngismus stridulus or rickets.

 

Option C. Vitamin K: Incorrect. Vitamin K deficiency primarily affects blood clotting and is not related to the development of rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Incorrect. Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) causes problems with collagen formation, leading to issues like easy bruising and poor wound healing, but it does not cause rickets or laryngismus stridulus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngismus stridulus is a manifestation of severe rickets caused by vitamin D deficiency, resulting in hypocalcemia and laryngeal muscle spasms.

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition
This is a case of Meleney's gangrene
The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false about the given condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

 

  • The image depicts necrotizing fasciitis of the abdominal wall, also known as Meleney's gangrene.
  • This condition is a severe soft tissue infection characterized by rapidly spreading inflammation and necrosis.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been shown to have some benefit in managing this condition.

 

Meleney's Gangrene (Necrotizing Fasciitis)

 

  • Clinical Features: Signs of local inflammation, skin gangrene, and features of septicemia such as hypotension and fever.
  • Investigation: Culture swab tests usually reveal aerobes (such as beta-hemolytic Streptococci) and anaerobes, making the condition often polymicrobial.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical: Radical wide debridement is necessary and may need to be repeated every 24-48 hours to manage the infection effectively.
    • Medical: Intravenous antibiotics are critical to treating the infection.
    • Adjunctive Therapy: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has some benefits and is used as an adjunct in the management of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition: True: Radical wide debridement is often needed repeatedly (every 24-48 hours) to control the spread of the infection and remove necrotic tissue.

 

Option B. This is a case of Meleney's gangrene: True: The condition shown in the image is Meleney's gangrene, a specific form of necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Option C. The condition is caused by beta Hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial: True: The infection can be caused by beta-hemolytic Streptococci and is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meleney's gangrene, or necrotizing fasciitis, requires aggressive surgical debridement, intravenous antibiotics, and may benefit from adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • The condition is often polymicrobial, involving both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gastroschisis

 

The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

 

The defects seen in the ventral body wall include:

 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital birth defect characterized by a defect in the abdominal wall, usually to the right of the umbilicus, which leads to the evisceration of the bowel loops which are not covered by a sac and are exposed to the external environment. The affected bowel loops can be damaged by exposure to amniotic fluid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Omphalocele: The bowel loops fail to return from the physiologic umbilical hernia. Since the umbilicus is covered by a reflection of the amnion, the omphalocele is also covered by amnion.

 

Congenital umbilical hernia: Umbilical hernia is a protrusion of the abdominal contents through a weakness in the umbilical ring, and ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital anomaly in which the urinary bladder is located outside the abdominal cavity.

 

 

Option B. Umbilical hernia: In case of umbilical hernia we do not usually see content of bowel coming out. Umbilical hernia is a cystic swelling which regresess when the baby is sleeping & appears during crying. No treatment is required for such condition.

 

Option D. Ectopia vesicae: Ectopia vesicae is a rare congenital malformation where the urinary bladder is located outside the lower abdominal wall. This condition is often associated with other abnormalities of the urinary tract and reproductive system. Ectopia vesicae is typically noticed at birth, and its severity can vary depending on the specific case

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital defect characterized by the herniation of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus, without a protective sac covering the contents.

questions.text:
A patient presents to you with fever, jaundice, and malaise. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (NEET PG 2023)

 

  • Anti-HBc (IgM): Positive
  • HBsAg: Positive
  • Anti-HBs: Negative
  • Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Acute hepatitis B

 

The serology results provide crucial information for diagnosing the type of hepatitis the patient has:

 

  1. HBsAg (Hepatitis B surface antigen): Positive
    • This indicates an active hepatitis B infection, as HBsAg is a marker of infection.
  2. Anti-HBc (IgM) (Hepatitis B core antibody, IgM): Positive
    • The presence of IgM anti-HBc indicates a recent infection or acute hepatitis B. IgM is produced early in the infection and suggests that the infection is recent.
  3. Anti-HBs (Hepatitis B surface antibody): Negative
    • The absence of anti-HBs indicates that the patient has not resolved the infection or been vaccinated. In the context of acute infection, this is expected as the patient has not yet developed immunity.
  4. Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
    • This indicates that the patient does not have hepatitis C.

 

Based on these results, the diagnosis is acute hepatitis B. The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc are key indicators of an acute infection.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Acute hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis B: Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed when HBsAg persists for more than six months and is typically associated with IgG anti-HBc, not IgM.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis C: This is ruled out by the negative anti-HCV antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc in a patient with fever, jaundice, and malaise strongly indicates acute hepatitis B.

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer visits you with a foot swelling and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Microscopic examination of granules from the discharge was performed and is as shown in the image below. Based on this information, what can be concluded about this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

 

  • The clinical scenario, along with the presence of sulfur granules in the image, suggests a diagnosis of mycetoma. This condition can be caused by either bacteria (Actinomycetoma) or fungi (Eumycetoma).
  • Mycetoma typically occurs following a trauma, and individuals engaged in agricultural work are at higher risk of developing this condition.

 

 

Clinical features (GST):

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

 

The discharge contains granules which are microcolonies of the causative organism. It is generally more invasive and can spread via the fascial planes (NOT Lymphatic) to the underlying muscle or bone. Dissemination is rare but can occur in lesions of the head and neck.

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
    • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  2. Actinomycetoma:
    • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
    • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is lymphocyte accumulation:

While lymphocytes can be present due to the chronic inflammatory nature of mycetoma, their accumulation is not a distinctive feature of this disease.

 

Option C. Undergoes lymphatic spread:

Mycetoma primarily spreads through contiguous tissue invasion rather than lymphatic spread. This is a feature that differentiates it from other infections like lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D. Involves only superficial tissues:

This is incorrect because mycetoma can involve both superficial and deep structures, including skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria and fungi, and is characterized by the presence of grains in discharging sinuses, often involving deep tissue structures beyond superficial tissues.

 

 

 

Reference –

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 401, 604, 605

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 689

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 1338, 1688

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection is being evaluated for infectivity status. Which of the following markers indicates high infectivity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBeAg

 

Explanation:

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) is a marker of viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection. Its presence indicates:

 

  • High levels of viral replication
  • Higher risk of transmission
  • Greater infectivity
  • Usually associated with higher HBV DNA levels
  • Important prognostic marker for complications like cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HBc: Indicates current or past HBV infection, but not infectivity

 

Option B. Anti-HBs: Indicates immunity (through vaccination or recovery), not infectivity

 

Option D. HBsAg: Indicates infection, but does not differentiate between high and low infectivity

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBeAg is a key marker of high viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: A neonate presents with fecal discharge from the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ileal diverticulum

 

Ileal diverticulum, commonly known as Meckel's diverticulum, is a congenital anomaly resulting from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline (omphalomesenteric) duct. This condition can result in a persistent connection between the intestine and the umbilicus. If this connection forms a fistula, fecal matter can discharge from the umbilicus.

Meckel's diverticulum often follows the "Rule of 2's": it occurs in about 2% of the population, is located approximately 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve, and is about 2 inches long. Symptoms often appear before the age of 2, and it can contain two types of ectopic tissue: gastric mucosa and pancreatic tissue.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastroschisis: This is a congenital defect where the abdominal wall does not form completely, leading to the intestines being exposed outside the body without a covering sac. It does not involve the formation of a fistula that would allow fecal discharge through the umbilicus.

 

Option B. Urachal fistula: This condition involves a patent urachus, a remnant of the allantois that normally obliterates after birth. It leads to urine discharge from the umbilicus, not fecal matter, as it connects the bladder to the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Omphalocele: This is a congenital defect in which the intestines, liver, and other organs remain outside the abdomen in a sac due to failure of the abdominal wall to close. It does not involve a fistula formation with the intestine, so fecal discharge does not occur from the umbilicus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel's diverticulum, due to its persistence of the vitelline duct, can lead to fecal discharge from the umbilicus, particularly when a fistula is present.

choices.text: Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

questions.text: Topical application of Mitomycin C is commonly used in the treatment of which condition? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prevention of scar tissue formation in Laryngotracheal stenosis

 

Explanation:


Mitomycin-C is used post-operatively in laryngotracheal reconstruction to prevent adhesions and fibrosis. In the treatment of subglottic stenosis, after procedures such as laryngotracheal reconstruction with cartilage grafts or resection of stenosed segments, Mitomycin-C is specifically applied to prevent scar tissue formation that could lead to recurrent stenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoscopic management of Angiofibroma: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used in the management of angiofibroma. These tumors are typically managed with surgical excision, preoperative embolization, or radiation in some cases.

 

Option B. Management of Sturge-Weber syndrome: This is incorrect. Mitomycin-C is not used for Sturge-Weber syndrome. This vascular condition typically requires different management approaches.

 

Option C. Treatment of Skull base osteomyelitis: This is incorrect. Skull base osteomyelitis treatment typically involves long-term antibiotics and sometimes surgical debridement, but Mitomycin-C application is not part of the standard treatment protocol.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mitomycin-C is an antifibrotic agent applied topically during laryngotracheal procedures to inhibit fibroblast proliferation and prevent adhesions and stenosis formation, making it particularly valuable in the management of laryngotracheal stenosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. He was the driver of the car, and upon impact, he had hit his abdomen against the steering wheel. Upon examination, the patient was conscious but complained of severe abdominal pain and tenderness upon palpation. The physician noted bruising and swelling in the abdominal area. Further evaluation revealed the evisceration of omentum, which was protruding through a laceration in the abdominal wall. What would be the best management of the same? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Emergency laparotomy

 

  • In the context of penetrating trauma, especially with evisceration (protrusion of internal tissues or organs through a wound), an emergency laparotomy becomes the procedure of choice to address any potential life-threatening injuries, stop bleeding, and repair damaged structures.
  • Evisceration is an indicator of full-thickness injury to the abdominal wall and potential underlying organ damage.

 

Indications for emergency laparotomy in penetrating trauma include:

 

  • Unstable patient
  • Features of peritonitis
  • Evisceration
  • Gunshot wounds

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Observation: Observation alone in this scenario would delay necessary intervention and could worsen the patient's outcome. Immediate surgical intervention is necessary to manage the evisceration and associated internal injuries.

 

Option C. Intravenous hydration: While IV hydration might be a part of the supportive care for a trauma patient, it is not the primary treatment for an evisceration injury. The priority would be to address the traumatic injury directly through surgery.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: This approach, like observation, is passive and is not suitable for traumatic injuries that are obviously severe, like evisceration. Delay in surgical intervention could lead to complications and worsen the patient's prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Evisceration in the context of trauma is a surgical emergency that requires immediate laparotomy to address potential internal injuries, control bleeding, and repair the damage.
  • Prompt surgical intervention is crucial to prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness, anemia, bony pain & hepatosplenomegaly. A histological picture is shown with cells in bone marrow. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluco-Cerebrosidase

 

The picture show macrophages with typical crumpled tissue paper appearance/ wrinkled appearance that is highly characteristic of Gaucher’s disease (most common lysosomal storage disease). Glucocerebrosides accumulate in reticuloendothelial system due to deficiency of enzyme β-Glucocerebrosidase. These patients have bony pain, pathological fractures, hepatosplenomegaly, but no mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Deficiency of Glucose 6 phosphatase is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD-I) or von Gierke disease. This disorder primarily affects glucose metabolism and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase A: Hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily affects the nervous system and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option D. Beta-Galactosidase: Deficiency of Beta-Galactosidase is associated with GM1 gangliosidosis. This lysosomal storage disorder primarily affects the nervous system and is not typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluco-Cerebrosidase, is associated with Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucosylceramide due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. Gaucher's disease can lead to the symptoms described, including hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and bony pain.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 235

choices.text: Lepromatous leprosy with positive Lepromin test
Tuberculoid leprosy with positive Lepromin test
Lepromatous leprosy with negative Lepromin test

questions.text: A patient presented with nodular lesions over the body, which are associated with slight anesthesia over the arm in the ulnar nerve distribution. Histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following options is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lepromatous leprosy with negative Lepromin test

 

The clinical presentation of the patient, including nodular lesions on the body and slight anesthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution, suggests a diagnosis of lepromatous leprosy. This form of leprosy is characterized by multiple, symmetrical skin lesions and sensory loss in a "glove and stocking" pattern.

 

Histopathological examination in lepromatous leprosy often shows features like the Grenz zone and a high bacterial load within macrophages.

 

The Lepromin test is used to assess the patient's cell-mediated immunity (CMI) to Mycobacterium leprae. In lepromatous leprosy, the CMI is severely compromised, leading to a negative Lepromin test result. This is in contrast to tuberculoid leprosy, where the CMI is strong, resulting in a positive Lepromin test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lepromatous leprosy with positive Lepromin test: This is incorrect because in lepromatous leprosy, the cell-mediated immunity is poor, leading to a negative Lepromin test. A positive Lepromin test is typically seen in tuberculoid leprosy, where the immune response is robust.

 

Option B. Tuberculoid leprosy with positive Lepromin test: While a positive Lepromin test is characteristic of tuberculoid leprosy, the clinical presentation described (nodular lesions, slight anesthesia in the ulnar nerve distribution) is not consistent with tuberculoid leprosy, which usually presents with fewer lesions and well-defined anesthetic patches.

 

Option D. ENL with negative Lepromin test: Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) is a complication of lepromatous leprosy characterized by painful nodules, fever, and systemic symptoms. However, ENL typically presents with constitutional symptoms like fever and arthralgia, which were not mentioned in the question. Therefore, this option is less likely to be correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In lepromatous leprosy, due to poor cell-mediated immunity, the Lepromin test is typically negative. This form of leprosy presents with multiple nodular lesions and sensory loss, often in a symmetrical distribution.

choices.text: Increased production of heat by liver

questions.text: Which physiological response is most likely to occur in a person exposed to high temperature while exercising vigorously to maintain internal body temperature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sweating and vasodilation in skin

 

When a person exercises vigorously, especially in high temperatures, the body needs to maintain its internal temperature within a safe range. During exercise, the sympathetic nervous system is activated, leading to muscle contractions and relaxations. This process generates heat as a byproduct. To prevent overheating, the body employs two key mechanisms: sweating and vasodilation.

 

  • Sweating: Sweat glands produce sweat, which is released onto the skin surface. As the sweat evaporates, it helps cool the body down.
  • Vasodilation: Blood vessels in the skin widen (dilate), increasing blood flow to the skin. This allows more heat to be transferred from the body core to the skin, where it can be dissipated into the environment.

 

These processes help in losing excess heat and maintaining a stable internal body temperature during vigorous exercise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shivering and vasoconstriction in skin: These responses occur in cold environments to conserve heat. Shivering generates heat through muscle activity, and vasoconstriction reduces blood flow to the skin to minimize heat loss. These mechanisms are not activated in high temperatures.

 

Option C. Increased production of heat by liver: Although the liver does produce some heat, the question specifically asks for the physiological responses to high temperature and exercise. The primary responses are mechanisms to lose heat, not produce more.

 

Option D. Decreased heart rate: During vigorous exercise, the heart rate typically increases, not decreases, to supply muscles with more oxygen and nutrients. This response is part of the body's overall effort to support increased physical activity and manage heat stress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During vigorous exercise in high temperatures, the body primarily responds by increasing sweating and vasodilation to dissipate heat and maintain a stable internal body temperature

questions.text: The cranial part of the accessory nerve supplies which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Superior constrictor

 

The cranial part of accessory nerve (CN XI) has a distinctive distribution pattern where it joins the vagus nerve (CN X) after both exit through the jugular foramen. After joining the vagus nerve, the cranial part of accessory nerve contributes fibers that are distributed with the pharyngeal branch of vagus nerve to supply 5 out of 6 pharyngeal muscles, including the superior constrictor muscle. It also supplies 4 out of 5 palatal muscles and all intrinsic muscles of the larynx. This unique pattern where the cranial root joins the vagus for distribution is important for understanding pharyngeal innervation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sternocleidomastoid - This muscle is supplied by the spinal part of the accessory nerve, not the cranial part. The spinal root emerges from the lateral aspect of the spinal cord, enters the cranium through foramen magnum, and then exits through jugular foramen.

 

Option B. Trapezius - Like the sternocleidomastoid, trapezius is also supplied by the spinal part of accessory nerve, not the cranial part. The spinal accessory component provides motor innervation to this muscle.

 

Option D. Stylopharyngeus - This is the only pharyngeal muscle not supplied by the cranial part of accessory nerve. It is uniquely innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX).

 

Educational Objective: The cranial part of accessory nerve joins the vagus nerve and supplies most pharyngeal muscles (5 out of 6) including the superior constrictor, while the spinal part independently supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
